title: 2. Essentials: Binning Point Data
text: icosa package approaches problem using rectangular grid, .e. grid cells rectangular shape. Instead, icosa relies tessellation regular icosahedron given resolution. procedure ends polyhedral object triangular faces higly isometric properties: similar shapes cells roughly equally distanced, similar cell area. bodies often called icospheres. grid looks like 3D (also plotted icosa, see later tutorial plotting):  Still, triangular grids somewhat unintuitive, distances cell can vary considerably: corner cell much farther away center side. reason, usually use inverted versions grids: triangle cell-midpoints become corners cells (.e. vertices), defines grid cells hexagonal - exactly 12 pentagons (vertices icosahedron used ). inverted version grid :

title: 2. Essentials: Binning Point Data
text: icosa loaded, can create penta-hexagonal grid single line code, using hexagrid() function: argument deg refers expected length edge length grid. given angular distance two cell vertices degrees - means degrees longitudinally (latitudinally equator), 1° =~111 km. used select tessellation vector, directly controlling grid resolution, describing faces icosahedron split . higher product vector, higher resolution - ie. cells grid. example c(2, 4) means original icosahedrons edges split 2 * 4 = 8 times. triangular grid (trigrid) inverted (vertices become cell midpoints), results penta-hexagonal grid. argument sf=TRUE indicates want create representation grid can used additional spatial operations using sf package, example 2D (projection-based) plotting. Since always needed, can significantly decrease performance, indicate need option. type name object, can immediately see properties structure resolution grid. important detail number faces 3d body (642) .e. number cells grid.
code: # create a trigrid class object hexa <- hexagrid(deg=5, sf=TRUE) ## Selecting hexagrid with tessellation vector: c(2, 4). ## Mean edge length: 4.993 degrees. hexa ## A/An hexagrid object with 1280 vertices, 1920 edges and 642 faces. ## The mean grid edge length is 555.24 km or 4.99 degrees. ## Use plot3d() to see a 3d render.

Additional functions provided allow plotting grids associated data, interaction grids raster vector objects, treating grids graphs. grids often called icospheres, important use material design, architecture, computer graphics chemistry.
